dsDescriptionValue.value: The Special Behavioral Survey (SBS) was conducted by the Centre hospitalier affilie universitaire de Quebec (CHA) under an Avahan monitoring and evaluation (M&E) grant from the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation. The SBS was conducted to validate the behavioral data gathered in a separate integrated biological and behavioral assessment (IBBA) by employing different data collection techniques. The SBS aimed firstly to validate key sexual behavior data items (collected through the IBBA two or three weeks prior to the SBS) from men who have sex with men (MSM), female sex workers (FSWs), and clients. Then secondly, the SBS collected additional data on sexual networks and concurrency not collected through the IBBA. The qualitative aspect of the study primarily aimed to gather information from sex workers and clients about the meaning of HIV in their lives, their perceptions of the HIV prevention programs being implemented, and their attitudes towards condom use.

keywordValue.value: Avahan, CSFW, Condom use,  FSWs, HIV prevention, Monitoring and evaluation, MSM, Perception; INSTITUTION: CHARME; STRATEGIC AREA: Avahan evaluation data

fields.value: The Special Behavioural Survey (SBS) was carried out in seven districts in Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh and Maharashtra  state selected for the IBBA: Mysore, Bellary, Belgaum and Bangalore Urban ( Karnataka); Guntur district (Andhra Pradesh) and Mumbai (Maharashtra) among FSWs, MSMs and clients of FSWs at different points of time. Both quantitative and qualitative components of SBS were collected but not in all the districts. The quantitative study of SBS was carried out in Karnataka among FSWs in Belgaum, Bellary and Bangalore from December 2005 to July 2006 (quantitative only), then in Bangalore urban and Mysore in 2007 (both quantitative and qualitative components).  The quantitative and qualitative studies of SBS among MSM in Karnataka were conducted in Bangalore urban (2006) and Mysore (2007). The only SBS among clients of FSWs was in Belgaum district in Karnataka (qualitative only). There was also a SBS, on both quantitative and qualitative components and among both MSM and FSW outside Karnataka: in Mumbai (2007) for FSWs and (2008) for MSM), and in Guntur district (Andhra Pradesh) for both FSWs and MSM (2007). The sampling frame, sample size and selection procedures for the quantitative part of the SBS were the same as that adopted in the IBBA in each district. A total of 85 clusters, that is, primary sampling units (PSUs) per district, were selected and an average of five interviews (FTFI and ICVI) was carried out per selected cluster. Conventional Cluster Sampling methodology was used for the selection of clusters for home-based, brothel-based, lodge-based and dabha-based sex work sites. (Dabhas are resting places on highways for long-distance truck drivers and motorists. These are also the places where sex workers sell sex to men who access the dabhas.) Time-Location Cluster Sampling methodology was used for the selection of clusters from street- and other public place-based sex work sites. From within the selected clusters, the respondents were selected randomly. A sample of 400 FSWs were enrolled for the study in each of the three districts. Since MSM are fewer in number in two of the three selected districts (Mysore and Bellary), MSM were studied only in Bangalore Urban district. A sample of 400 MSM were drawn from the district.

files.description: This document consists of questionnaires, interview guidelines (IDs and FGDs), study procedures and methodology etc. of SBS (By CHARME India)
